Other News - US State Department official said the US has asked the UN Security Council to discuss North Korea's missile launches and the possibility of an "escalatory DPRK provocation". In related news, North Korean official said US President Trump's remarks over the weekend sound like a threat but are a sign of fear and the official warned that Trump may need to rethink or face catastrophic consequences, while South Korea expects North Korea provocation and a possible engine test before Christmas. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump reiterated US and China are doing well in its trade deal. (Newswires)

There were unconfirmed reports citing a trade source which noted the December 15th tariffs are going ahead and China is preparing for them, while FBN's Lawrence separately stated December 15th China tariffs are currently still scheduled to take effect. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi hopes to achieve a China-EU investment agreement as soon as is possible, according to Chinese state TV. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Election ICM Research Polls: Conservatives 42% (Unch.), Labour 36% (+1), Lib Dems 12% (-1), Brexit Party 3% (Unch.), conducted December 6th-9th. (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

US government believes that Iran is behind a series of increasingly sophisticated rocket attacks on joint US-Iraq military facilities in Iraq, according to reports citing US officials. (CNN)

US State Department official said the US has asked the UN Security Council to discuss North Korea's missile launches and the possibility of an "escalatory DPRK provocation". (Newswires)

North Korean official said US President Trump's remarks over the weekend sound like a threat but are a sign of fear and the official warned that Trump may need to rethink or face catastrophic consequences. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump said we are doing well on USMCA and that he hears from unions it is looking very good. In related news, the White House and Democrats reached a tentative deal on USMCA in which the House could vote on the deal on 18th December according to source, while it was also reported that USTR Lighthizer and Trump Advisor Jared Kushner are heading to Mexico tomorrow for talks on completion of agreement on re-negotiated NAFTA. (CNBC)

Mexico President Lopez Obrador said Mexican Senators have accepted proposed changes to USMCA and that it is up to the US now to make the next move, while Obrador 'respectfully requests' US House Speaker Pelosi make a decision about USMCA. (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

The US day began on a note of caution, with traders citing soft China trade data, which highlights the fallout from trade wars, as well as key risk events in the week (Fed, ECB) and the looming 15th December US tariff deadline. ArQule (ARQL) doubled in value after Merck (MRK) agreed to acquire it for USD 2.7bln to deepen its cancer treatment offerings; on a similar vein, Synthorx (THOR) nearly tripled in value after Sanofi (SAN FP, SNY) agreed to acquire it for USD 2.5bln, giving the French giant access to the lucrative THOR-707 solid tumour treatment. The flurry of M&A helped the biotech sector (XBI) continue its recent strength; Bristol-Myers (BMY) also made solid gains after presenting a slew of promising data over the weekend. Canopy Growth (CGC) surged after appointing Constellation Brands (STZ) CFO as its new CEO, with desks noting the growing likelihood of STZ making a full ownership bid. PG&E (PCG) surged on its USD 13.5bln settlement agreement with fire victims, clearing the way for finalizing its bankruptcy plan. Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) benefitted from stronger metals prices. SPX -0.32% at 3136; NDX -0.4% at 8363; DJIA -0.38% at 27910.

Yields were little changed in the TPLEX, ahead of a key week for event risk (Fed, ECB, and the looming 15th December US/China tariff deadline); it has seen a cautious start to the week. Major curve spreads had a bias towards narrowing, though the size of the moves is within 2bps. The US Treasury today sold a new 3-year note (USD 38bln), which stopped through by 0.2bps. Cover came in above recent averages; the direct bid and the indirect bid were fairly steady, though directs stepped up participation. On Tuesday, the UST will re-open 10-year (USD 24bln, Tue) and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Wed), for a total of USD 78bln of supply in the week; there will be USD 26bln of cash via redemptions and coupon payments, implying net new cash around USD 54bln. BMO notes that this collateral will settle on Monday, December 16, and it sees parallels between these dynamics and those in the lead up to the repo volatility on September 16. "The parallels between the two dates are striking: both are Monday’s with USD 54bln in new coupon supply, and large expected corporate tax payments." BMO also notes that in each of the last three years, the December corporate tax payment was larger than the September, though this need not necessarily be the case. "Of course, the repo world is significantly different than just three months ago – with hundreds of billions of Fed injections having occurred over the intervening period," and net, BMO expects slight upward pressure on funding costs, but nothing close to what we saw around the last large corporate tax payment. "Instead, attention rightfully should focus on the upcoming year-end funding squeeze. US T-note futures settle 3 ticks higher at 129-00.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 9th December 2019: Cautious start to the week ahead of key event risk
content:
• SNAPSHOT: Equities lower, Treasuries up, Crude down, Dollar down.
  • REAR VIEW: USMCA deal close; weak China trade data; decent German trade data; Japan GDP in Q3 revised up significantly.
  • COMING UP: RBA’s Lowe; China CPI/PPI, UK data; Germany ZEW; EU General Affairs Council.

* MARKET WRAP: The US day began on a note of caution, with traders citing soft China trade data, which highlights the fallout from trade wars, as well as key risk events in the week (Fed, ECB) and the looming 15th December US tariff deadline (see our analysis here). The fixed income complex was on the front foot, with the curve having a bias towards flattening, while equity futures were mostly horizontal; activity currencies were under also pressure (AUD stood out, after the China data), while gold was firmer. There has been positive newsflow on the USMCA, and while headliens were supporting MXN and CAD, there was little follow-through in other risk assets.

* USMCA: US and Mexican negotiators are reportedly "very close" to finalizing the USMCA, a Washington-based source told Reuters on the weekend. House Speaker Pelosi still needed to agree on revisions to the pact; Democrats have concerns over the enforcement of labour and environmental provisions in the current draft. Mexico's deputy foreign minister Seade has also stated a deal was close, and he is likely to return to Washington on Monday to continue talks; on Friday, Seade said that many issues still needed to be resolved. Reuters' report added that one point of contention is over steel, after USTR Lighthizer made a last-minute demand for a revised definition of what would constitute 'North American steel' under automotive rules of origin. Meanwhile, US President Trump on the weekend tweeted that if Speaker Pelosi, "doesn’t move quickly" to approve the deal, it "will collapse!" On Monday, Mexico President Lopez Obrador said Mexican Senators had accepted proposed changes to USMCA, and it was now up to US now to make the next move; Obrador 'respectfully requested' US House Speaker Pelosi make a decision about USMCA. Later, US Labour Leader Trumka said there was an agreement on the USMCA, with the deal including major victories for labour, suggesting passage could be smooth. The report was followed up with sources reports stating the deal could be finalised within 24 hours. However, a Senior Democratic Aide noted the Democrats are still studying the deal and ultimately, Pelosi is to make the final decision. CNBC later stated a tentative deal h as been agreed on USMCA, according to sources, who note the House could vote on the deal on 18th December.

* CHINA NOV TRADE BALANCE: China's November trade surplus narrowed to USD 38.73bln (exp. USD 46.30bln, prev. USD 42.81bln); exports shrank for the fourth consecutive month (-1.1% Y/Y, exp. +1.0%), highlighting pressures manufacturers are facing from the US/China trade war, though the growth in imports may be a sign that Beijing's stimulus efforts are helping (+0.3% Y/Y, the first Y/Y growth since April; exp. -1.8% Y/Y) – analysts will be monitoring whether this trend is sustained in the data ahead. Meanwhile, some calculations inferred the trade surplus with the US narrowed to USD 24.60bln versus USD 26.45bln in October.

* US/CHINA: The Chinese government has ordered all departments to remove all foreign hardware and software within the next three years, the FT reported. Last week issued some tariff waivers for imports of US soybeans and pork, traders said Chinese importers were to begin purchases of US soybeans for January/February shipments, with at least two cargoes (120k tonnes) sold to China. This figure was later updated to show 5 cargoes have been purchased by Chinese Importers which equates to roughly 300k tonnes of US soybeans.

* GERMANY TRADE BALANCE: The trade surplus widened in October to EUR 20.6bln (it was expected to narrow to 19.0bln from 19.2bln). Exports began Q4 in decent fashion, rising 1.2% M/M, which analysts were more encouraged by given the 1.5% M/M rise in September. Imports were flat. "Net trade boosted GDP growth significantly in Q3, so mean reversion points to a setback in Q2, but we concede that the October data point to resiliency," Pantheon Macroeconomics said, "the monthly data have been a poor guide to the quarterly GDP numbers this year, so we are less certain than usual about the underlying trend; at the very least we need to see more data, especially on import and export prices, which usually are a key driver of the deflated GDP net trade data." Pantheon says that one thing that is clear now though is that net exports will look better in 2019 than 2018.

* EUROZONE SENTIX: The headline EU Sentix Index printed +0.7 in December, beating expectations of -4.9 from -4.5. The rise came despite some jitters in equity markets at the beginning of the month, with the headline underpinned by rises in expectations (back above zero) and the current situation index. Analysts said the data signals investors may be regaining confidence, and if it is sustained, may knock-on to other confidence indicators.

* JAPAN Q3 GDP: The final reading saw a significant upward revision to Japanese GDP in Q3, printing 1.8% Q/Q annualised (vs. expected +0.6%; +0.4% Q/Q from +0.2%). The revisions were driven by stronger capital investment and private consumption.

* BOJ: The BOJ may offer a bleaker assessment on factory output than in October at its meeting on 19th December, sources told Reuters, underscoring its concern over the broadening fallout from the US/China trade war, and slowing global demand. The article noted that a downgrade in the BOJ’s view on factory output, considered a key driver of growth, will cast doubt on its argument that Japan’s economy will sustain a moderate expansion as robust domestic demand make up for weak exports. On Thursday, the BOJ’s quarterly Tankan survey is expected to show large manufacturers remain under pressure, with the street looking for the lowest print in seven years. The two key metrics to monitor are the Large Manufacturers Index (Seen coming in at 2 vs 5 in Q3), though the Large-Non-Manufacturers Index will also be important (seen at 16 vs 21 in Q3). The data will be framed in the context of the domestic spending situation, which has taken a hit from the consumption tax hike in the quarter, and exports continue to take a hit from trade wars.

* WTI (F0) SETTLES USD 0.18 LOWER AT USD 59.02; BRENT (G0) SETTLES USD 0.14 LOWER AT USD 64.25: Crude markets have been consolidating from their multi-month highs made on the back of the OPEC+ meeting last week. The benchmarks were offered in the Asia/European session on the back of weaker trade data out of China, although below the headline, the world’s largest crude importer actually increased its imports of oil on the month; Citi energy analysts go on to highlight the rolling 12-month crude oil import average remains robust, indicative of its demand. The bank also notes the market is taking some time to digest the recent OPEC+ production cuts, where coverage has been presenting the deal as a bullish surprise, but follow-through demand has been limited as of yet, seeing the cut as a defensive move that reduces, rather than eliminates, an H1 2020 surplus. Looking ahead to this week’s energy inventories, current expectations see crude stocks drawing 3.1mln bbls, distillates building 1.8mln bbls and gasoline building 2.7mnl bbls; Genscape forecast Cushing stocks drawing 2.3mln bbls.

* SPX -0.32% at 3136; NDX -0.4% at 8363; DJIA -0.38% at 27910. SECTORS: consumer staples +0.15%, consumer discretionary +0.1%, materials -0.1%, energy -0.25%, telecoms -0.3%, financials -0.3%, industrials -0.35%, communications -0.4%, IT -0.5%, utilities -0.5%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: ArQule (ARQL) doubled in value after Merck (MRK) agreed to acquire it for USD 2.7bln to deepen its cancer treatment offerings; on a similar vein, Synthorx (THOR) nearly tripled in value after Sanofi (SAN FP, SNY) agreed to acquire it for USD 2.5bln, giving the French giant access to the lucrative THOR-707 solid tumour treatment. The flurry of M&A helped the biotech sector (XBI) continue its recent strength; Bristol-Myers (BMY) also made solid gains after presenting a slew of promising data over the weekend. Canopy Growth (CGC) surged after appointing Constellation Brands (STZ) CFO as its new CEO, with desks noting the growing likelihood of STZ making a full ownership bid. PG&E (PCG) surged on its USD 13.5bln settlement agreement with fire victims, clearing the way for finalizing its bankruptcy plan. Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) benefitted from stronger metals prices.

* BROKER MOVES: Qorvo (QRVO) and Skyworks (SWKS) both benefitted from a double upgrade to Buy at BofAML on anticipation of 5G opportunities. 3M (MMM) opened on the back foot on a Citi downgrade, although did pare somewhat through the session, whilst Fortive (FTV) was firmer after the same analyst upgraded it due to it being a more worthy competitor when selecting an industrial amid the recent downturn. Macy’s (M) underperformance intensified as Goldman downgraded the retailer suggesting a troubled outlook, Barron’s also mentioned the name negatively.

* CANADA HOUSING STARTS: Canadian housing starts printed 201.3k in November, against an expected 205k, and a revised down prior 200.7k. Crucially, it held above the 200k level for a sixth consecutive month in November, and with another decent month for permits, home building is on course to remain firm through the turn of the year, RBC said, with the bank looking for the data to stabilise around the 200k rate seen YTD.

* NORTH KOREA: North Korea state media reported it carried out a "very important" test at its Sohae satellite launch site, a testing facility that US officials had previously said Pyongyang had pledged to close. The exact test was not specified however it was apparently a static test of a rocket engine instead of a missile launch. Where a nuclear affairs expert at MIT highlighted if it is a static engine test for a new solid or liquid fuel missile, it is a strong signal “the door for diplomacy is quickly slamming, if it isn’t already”. US President Trump responded by tweeting NK leader Kim was "too smart and has far too much to lose, everything actually, if he acts in a hostile way." On Monday, a North Korean official said US President Trump's remarks over the weekend sounded like a threat, but was a sign of fear; the official warned that Trump may need to rethink, or face catastrophic consequences. A US State Department Official later announced the US has asked the UN Security Council to discuss the latest missile launches and the possibility of an “escalatory DPRK provocation”.

* UK ELECTION: Weekend polls put PM Johnson’s Conservatives between 8-15 points in front of opposition Labour ahead of Thursday’s General Election. On Tuesday at 10pm, YouGov’s final MRP model will be published – the pollster’s model accurately predicted the hung parliament in 2017; the initial reiteration this season modelled a 68 seat Tory majority (with a Conservative vote share of 43%, Labour 32%). PM Johnson said "We are still not quite there yet and do not forget what happened in 2017. This is a close fought election". An ICM poll on Monday saw the Tory/Labour spread narrow to 6 points, the bottom-end of the recent range. Regarding opinion polling this week, analysts note that in 2017, polls were published right up until the election day itself, and it therefore appears that polls can be published up until 2359 GMT on Wednesday; regulator OFCOM states that broadcasters may not, however, publish the results of any opinion poll on election day itself.

* HOUSE IMPEACHMENT VOTE: House Speaker Pelosi last week indicated that a full House vote on impeachment will come by the end of the year; analysts think a vote could happen before 20th December, though it is possible it could come as soon as this week. The House Judiciary Committee panel will consider the specific articles of impeachment after a hearing on Monday. Lawmakers are divided along party lines (Democrats back impeachment; the Republicans do not). Looking ahead, there seems to be a very a high hurdle than any impeachment proceedings could secure the 66% of support needed in the Republican-controlled Senate.

* HONG KONG: On the six-month anniversary of protests, thousands of demonstrators 8th December marched through the streets of Hong Kong, the BBC reported, the largest anti-government rally in months. Organisers claimed 800k people took part, while official figures claim 183k participated -- some commentators said the size of the crowd suggested that the victory of pro-democracy candidates in local elections a fortnight ago has not quelled concerns about HK's pro-China leadership and lack of political autonomy. The march was organised by The Civil Human Rights Front, a pro-democracy group, the first such protest by that group to receive police approval since August.

* PBOC: PBOC adviser Liu Shijin said China’s potential economic growth could be between 5-6% over the next five years. China's monetary policy was already quite loose, Liu said, and attempting to stoke above potential growth could cause the economy to 'fall off a cliff'. Chinese growth slowed to 6.0% in Q3 amid slowing domestic demand and the US/China trade war, the weakest rate in almost three decades, and at the bottom of the government's 6.0-6.5% target range. China has resisted mass stimulus due to financial stability risks and high levels of debt; PBOC governor Yi Gang last week reiterated the central bank would not resort to QE, and reiterated a commitment to maintaining a prudent monetary policy.

* ESKOM: State utility Eskom announced stage four power cuts after a few days of rolling blackouts (sources see load shedding could move to level six of eight); Eskom said it expects load shedding to continue for the rest of the week due to technical issues. NOTE: Stage four is the most severe that SA has experienced, including four hours of blackouts daily. Later, it was reported load shedding will move to stage six from 18:00 local time today. Desks note that the more severe the power cuts are, the more impact you'd expect to see on SA's Q4 GDP growth.

* US/FRANCE: FinMin Le Maire said France is ready to challenge US President Trump at the WTO over his threat to slap tariffs on French goods in retaliation for a French digital tax on tech companies. Le Maire said France was willing to discuss a global digital tax with the US at either the OECD or EU level, adding that new EU economy commissioner Gentiloni had already proposed to restart talks. The EU Commission has recently said it would "react as one and remain united" with France, as it does in any trade matter.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES SETTLE 3 TICKS HIGHER AT 129-00. Yields were little changed in the TPLEX, ahead of a key week for event risk (Fed, ECB, and the looming 15th December US/China tariff deadline); it has seen a cautious start to the week. Major curve spreads had a bias towards narrowing, though the size of the moves is within 2bps. The US Treasury today sold a new 3-year note (USD 38bln), which stopped through by 0.2bps. Cover came in above recent averages; the direct bid and the indirect bid were fairly steady, though directs stepped up participation. On Tuesday, the UST will re-open 10-year (USD 24bln, Tue) and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Wed), for a total of USD 78bln of supply in the week; there will be USD 26bln of cash via redemptions and coupon payments, implying net new cash around USD 54bln. BMO notes that this collateral will settle on Monday, December 16, and it sees parallels between these dynamics and those in the lead up to the repo volatility on September 16. "The parallels between the two dates are striking: both are Monday’s with USD 54bln in new coupon supply, and large expected corporate tax payments." BMO also notes that in each of the last three years, the December corporate tax payment was larger than the September, though this need not necessarily be the case. "Of course, the repo world is significantly different than just three months ago – with hundreds of billions of Fed injections having occurred over the intervening period," and net, BMO expects slight upward pressure on funding costs, but nothing close to what we saw around the last large corporate tax payment. "Instead, attention rightfully should focus on the upcoming year-end funding squeeze."

* USD: The greenback remains around Friday’s levels after the dust settled following the latest jobs report. Ranges for the dollar index were thin trading in between 97.56 and 97.72 as participants eye key risk events later in the week, with FOMC, UK Election and December 15th China tariffs looming.

* CAD/MXN: The USMCA currencies both bid against the buck today following positive developments on the USMCA front where Mexico Senators agreed to the changes made and the US Republicans and Democrats reportedly reached a tentative agreement, according to sources, with a vote likely on December 18th. The Loonie pared back some of Friday’s losses after a poor jobs report but still remains worse off with USDCAD breaching 1.3225 to the downside from highs of 1.3265 to find support at the 55dma at 1.3221. USDMXN continues its run towards the 19-handle in December after an initial weak start of the month for the Buck (despite on Friday after the stellar jobs report, although MXN still traded firmer against the Buck) on the continued positive rhetoric regarding USMCA.

* GBP: Continues to appreciate ahead of Thursday's election. The latest polls signal Tories lead Labour by a margin of between 8-15 points; attention will be on YouGov's model, released 2200 GMT on Tuesday (the model accurately predicted the 2017 election outcome). Meanwhile, betting markets imply a 75-80% probability that the Tories will win a majority, which is a little high for some, given the reliability of opinion polls.

* Havens (JPY, XAU, CHF): JPY traded relatively flat against the greenback trading in a range between 108.44-67 despite a strong GDP figure from the nation and poor China trade data. XAU: Gold initially gave back some of last Friday’s losses after the NFP boost, however like JPY traded relatively flat heading into the Asia session, and is relatively unchanged going into APAC. Desks notes XAU trade may quieten down into the end of the year, but there are some suggesting that seasonality may play a role in supporting prices in January (desks note that, last year, some of that seasonal effect did start to show in December, however). CHF however was firmer against the USD, GBP and EUR amid its adjusted unemployment rate remaining unchanged in line with analyst expectations; SNB rate decision later this week.

* TRY, ZAR, BRL: A livelier start for certain regional currencies like the TRY that failed to derive any support from loan-related changes to Turkish bank RRRs and the ZAR feeling more pain from Eskom power outages reaching fresh record levels. Conversely, the BRL held up well in the face of generally risk-off or jittery sentiment in the run up to the Fed, BCB, SNB and ECB this week with many anticipating a final Selic rate cut in the cycle.

subject: US T-Note (H20) futures settle 3 ticks higher at 129-00
analysis_details: Yields were little changed in the TPLEX, ahead of a key week for event risk (Fed, ECB, and the looming 15th December US/China tariff deadline); it has seen a cautious start to the week. Major curve spreads had a bias towards narrowing, though the size of the moves is within 2bps. The US Treasury today sold a new 3-year note (USD 38bln), which stopped through by 0.2bps. Cover came in above recent averages; the direct bid and the indirect bid were fairly steady, though directs stepped up participation. On Tuesday, the UST will re-open 10-year (USD 24bln, Tue) and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Wed), for a total of USD 78bln of supply in the week; there will be USD 26bln of cash via redemptions and coupon payments, implying net new cash around USD 54bln. BMO notes that this collateral will settle on Monday, December 16, and it sees parallels between these dynamics and those in the lead up to the repo volatility on September 16. "The parallels between the two dates are striking: both are Monday’s with USD 54bln in new coupon supply, and large expected corporate tax payments." BMO also notes that in each of the last three years, the December corporate tax payment was larger than the September, though this need not necessarily be the case. "Of course, the repo world is significantly different than just three months ago – with hundreds of billions of Fed injections having occurred over the intervening period," and net, BMO expects slight upward pressure on funding costs, but nothing close to what we saw around the last large corporate tax payment. "Instead, attention rightfully should focus on the upcoming year-end funding squeeze."

subject: Newsquawk Bond Auction Preview: US to sell USD 38bln of 3-year notes at 1130 ET/1630 GMT on 9th December 2019
content:
THIS WEEK'S AUCTIONS: The US Treasury will this week sell a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Mon), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Tue) and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Wed), for a total of USD 78bln. This week, there will be USD 26bln of cash via redemptions and coupon payments.  

REPO VOLATILITY: BMO notes that this collateral will settle on Monday, December 16, and it sees parallels between these dynamics and those in the lead up to the repo volatility on September 16. "The parallels between the two dates are striking: both are Monday’s with USD 54bln in new coupon supply, and large expected corporate tax payments." BMO also notes that in each of the last three years, the December corporate tax payment was larger than the September, though this need not necessarily be the case. "Of course, the repo world is significantly different than just three months ago – with hundreds of billions of Fed injections having occurred over the intervening period," and net, BMO expects slight upward pressure on funding costs, but nothing close to what we saw around the last large corporate tax payment. "Instead, attention rightfully should focus on the upcoming year-end funding squeeze." 

3-YEAR PREVIEW: BMO thinks the Treasury sell-off over the last few sessions incorporates decent concession for the 3s auction, and says the sector looks attractive on a 2s/3s/s5s butterfly, which is near the cheapest levels seen in a year. BMO notes that, seasonally, the December auction is on the strong side of neutral, with five of the last 11 in December stopping through. However, BMO cautions that a Fed pause is well reflected in market pricing, some players in the front end will be monitoring for any hawkish surprise; BMO says the dynamic could inspire some investor hesitation in adding short duration exposure until after the FOMC. BMO also notes that SOMA will not be buying today, however, general collateral is trading in line with 3s, which is unlikely to prompt any incremental demand upside.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar drifts from post-NFP peaks, but Loonie defies more downbeat data
content:
USD

It’s been a relatively slow grind in fairly quiet trade, but the Greenback has kicked off the new and potentially pivotal week mostly on the back foot amidst mildly softer US Treasury yields and a flatter curve after last Friday’s post-jobs data bear steepening. The DXY has meandered between 97.556-725 parameters with little impetus drawn from an uptick in employment trends in the absence of anything else on Monday’s US agenda and as attention switches to the December FOMC.

CAD/MXN

The Loonie has managed to rebound further from lows hit in wake of Friday’s dire Canadian labour report even though housing starts and building permits both missed consensus to add more doubt to the BoC’s improved outlook for and assessment of the domestic economy. The catalyst, positive news on the USMCA that has also lifted the Mexican Peso, as latest reports suggest a deal could be done in the next 24 hours following approval of proposed changes to the agreement by Mexico’s Senate. Usd/Cad currently probing below 1.3225 and Usd/Mxn around 19.2300 at one stage.

GBP/CHF/EUR/NZD/JPY/AUD 

The Pound remains marginally ahead of its G10 counterparts, but some distance from early Monday highs after the latest pre-UK election poll showing a narrower lead for the Conservatives over main rival and opposition party Labour. In fact, the ICM results put the gap at 6% points vs 7% previously and even smaller than the lowest weekend survey differential to leave Cable close to 1.3150 and Eur/Gbp nearer the top of a 0.8426-0.8394 band, as the single currency consolidated above 1.1050 against the US Dollar. Meanwhile, the Franc pared losses and reclaimed parity+ status, but the Yen lost momentum on unwinding safe-haven flows, as Usd/Jpy rebounded from sub-108.50 and well ahead of technical support at 108.23. Elsewhere, the Antipodeans remain mixed with the Aussie still lagging on Chinese growth trade jitters after data and ahead of US import tariff deadline day, as Aud/Usd remained under 0.6850 in contrast to Nzd/Usd holding firm above 0.6550 and the Aud/Nzd cross hovering just over the 1.0400 mark.

SEK/NOK

The Scandi Kronas have extended declines with Eur/Sek back above 10.5500 at one stage and Eur/Nok up over 10.1300 on the back of technically delayed and mixed monthly Norwegian GDP for October (mainland growth feeble vs more robust oil-fuelled expansion offshore).

EM 

A livelier start for certain regional currencies like the Try that failed to derive any support from loan-related changes to Turkish bank RRRs and the Zar feeling more pain from Eskom power outages reaching fresh record levels. Conversely, the Brl held up well in the face of generally risk-off or jittery sentiment in the run up to the Fed, BCB, SNB and ECB this week with many anticipating a final Selic rate cut in the cycle.

Newsquawk Central Banks - PREVIEW: FOMC Meeting (December 2019)
content:
• The FOMC is expected to leave rates unchanged at 1.50-1.75%. Attention will be on the forward guidance elements, updated forecasts and ‘dot plot’. In his press conference, Chair Powell may be asked to clarify what factors the Fed needs to be in place that would amount to a “material reassessment” of the outlook – both on the upside and downside – that may result in the FOMC changing its policy stance. Ultimately, Powell is expected to reiterate an optimistic view of the US economy, though caution on familiar risks while reiterating a data-dependent outlook (NOTE: the FOMC precedes a potential boosting of US tariffs on Chinese imports on 15th December). Rate decision will be published along with updated economic projections at 1900 GMT/1400 ET on 11th December 2019; the post-meeting press conference with Chair Powell will commence at 1930 GMT/1430 ET. subject: Newsquawk Central Banks - PREVIEW: ECB policy decision (December 2019)
content:
• Christine Lagarde's first meeting as ECB President is not expected to deliver any material changes to current monetary policy settings, given that the September easing measures are yet to take full effect, and there is no urgency to add further accommodation at this stage as the ECB assesses the impact of its September easing. The focus will therefore fall on how Lagarde intends to run the central bank, and its upcoming strategic policy review, which will likely be formally announced at the December confab; but there is a risk that this meeting will be light on details, which may possibly result in horizontal price action. Many believe Lagarde's first task will be uniting a divided Governing Council, where there are mixed views on the efficacy and risks of loose(r) policy, as well as the practicalities of the ECB’s decision-making functions. Lagarde is also expected to reiterate her call on fiscal authorities to do more to support the Eurozone economy. Elsewhere, updated economic projections may see near-term growth forecasts nudged up slightly, though further forecasts are subject to downside risks; inflation forecasts are seen little changed. subject: Mexico President Lopez Obrador says Mexican Senators have accepted proposed changes to USMCA, up to US now to make the next move; Obrador 'respectfully requests' US House Speaker Pelosi make a decision about USMCA
reaction_details: • CAD (USDCAD hit a new LOD around 1.3235) and MXN (USDMXN fell to 19.2460 from around 19.28) see some modest upside against the USD after Obrador's remarks
analysis_details:
• US and Mexican negotiators were reportedly "very close" to finalizing the USMCA, a Washington-based source told Reuters on the weekend.
  • House Speaker Pelosi still needed to agree on revisions to the pact; Democrats have concerns over the enforcement of labour and environmental provisions in the current draft.
  • Mexico's deputy foreign minister Seade has also stated a deal was close, and he is likely to return to Washington on Monday to continue talks; on Friday, Seade said that many issues still needed to be resolved.
  • The Reuters' report added that one point of contention was over steel, after USTR Lighthizer made a last-minute demand for a revised definition of what would constitute 'North American steel' under automotive rules of origin.
  • Meanwhile, US President Trump on the weekend tweeted that if Speaker Pelosi, "doesn’t move quickly" to approve the deal, it "will collapse!"

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 9th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Macy's Inc. (M) (Consumer Discretionary/Department Stores) has been downgraded to Sell from Neutral at Goldman Sachs
  • Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) (Health Care/Health Care Distributors) announced positive data over the weekend
  • Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) and Qorvo (QRVO) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) have both been double-upgraded to Buy from Underperform by BofAML

9th December 2019

  • In this week’s Barron’s publication, Macy’s (M) was mentioned with scepticism this holiday season, Expedia (EXPE) was mentioned as a buy despite management changes, Capital One (COF) was suggested to have upside amid its discount to its peers, Skechers (SKX) was mentioned positively on potential earnings growth to match Nike (NKE) and low valuation, whilst the cover story spoke in favour of five small cap stocks poised to rally in 2020 on an improving economy and earnings, namely, Darling Ingredients (DAR), Compass Diversified (CODI), Qualys (QLYS), Lincoln Electric (LECO) and Hannon Armstrong Sustainable Infrastructure Capital (HASI).

DOW

  • 3M Company (MMM) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) has been downgraded to Neutral from Buy at Citi, with its PT unchanged at USD 180 (last closed at USD 171.47), where analyst Andrew Kaplowitz cites IP peaking in December 2018, with the sector in a “mild downturn” with some expected choppiness ahead; Kaplowitz advised on stock-selectiveness, and as of such, upgraded Fortive Corp (FTV) (Industrials/Industrial Machinery) to Buy from Neutral, raising its PT to USD 84 from USD 76 (last closed at USD 72.87), due to his preference for companies with a "combination of self-help runway and exposure to resilient long-cycle and/or 'secular' growth end markets."
  • Johnson & Johnson’s (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) Janssen has acquired XBiotech Inc’s (XBIT) (Health Care/Biotechnology) novel antibody bermekimab for USD 750mln, in addition to potential milestone payments for the non-dermatological disease treatment.
  • Merck and Co Inc (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) is to acquire ArQule (ARQL) (Health Care/Biotechnology) for an equity value of USD 2.7bln, or USD 20/share, more than double its last closing price of USD 9.66/share. ArQule’s pinnacle treatment is ARQ 531, an oral Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor in Phase-2 dose expansion study for patients with B-cell malignancies.
  • Pfizer Inc. (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and Sangamo Therapeutics Inc (SGMO) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced generally positive results from its severe hemophilia gene therapy, SB-525, as part of their Phase 1/2 Alta study.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) lead the Box Office for a third week straight with its Frozen 2, with this weekend’s North American ticket sales cumulating USD 34.7mln.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) CEO Bezos has said the tech titan will continue to support the Department of Defense amid its ongoing dispute with Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software), after the latter won the Pentagon’s USD 10bln cloud computing JEDI contract.
  • Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) and Qorvo (QRVO) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) have both been double-upgraded to Buy from Underperform by BofAML analyst Vivek Arya, raising PTs on the two names, with SWKS boosted to USD 122 from USD 92 (last closed at 101.36) and QRVO lifted to USD 130 from USD 80 (last closed at 106.62), citing the emerging opportunities from 5G technology, in addition to their underperformance among SOX peers.
  • Tesla Inc (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) has been cleared in court over the defamation lawsuit brought against him by the British diver.

S&P 500

  • AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) released a slew of positive treatment data over the weekend.
  • Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) (Health Care/Health Care Distributors) and Bluebird Bio Inc (BLUE) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced top-line results from their multiple myeloma Phase 2 study, KarMMa, evaluating idecabtagene vicleucel, which met its primary and secondary endpoints. Elsewhere, BMY showed positive results from its lisocabtagene maraleucel study, meeting its endpoints for the therapy of B-cell lymphomas. BMY and Pfizer Inc. (PFE) also presented positive safety and effectiveness results from cancer treatment, Eliquis.
  • Macy's Inc. (M) (Consumer Discretionary/Department Stores) has been downgraded to Sell from Neutral at Goldman Sachs with a PT cut to USD 12 from USD 17 (last closed at USD 15.15), where analyst Alexandra Walvis sees significant downside ahead, despite its already YTD underperformance, with other analysts underestimating its negative operating leverage.
  • Realty Income Corporation (O) (Real Estate/Retail REITs) has filed to sell 33.4mln shares of common stock.

OTHER

  • Canopy Growth Corporation (CGC) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) has announced Constellation Brands’ (STZ) (Consumer Staples/Distillers & Vintners) CFO and existing CGC chairman, David Klein, as its new CEO, effective January 14th; STZ has an existing 38% stake in CGC.
  • Ericsson (ERICB SS, ERIC) (Information Technology/Communications Equipment) has agreed to pay over USD 1bln to settle a US investigation into foreign bribery involving high-level executives. The settlement was in-line with the Co’s previously disclosed provisions, FT reported.
  • PG&E Corp (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) has agreed to the USD 13.5bln settlement with fire victims from the 2017 Northern California wildfires and 2018 camp fire, resolving all claims and as of such, the co will finalise its bankruptcy plan. However, WSJ later reported that the settlement is threatening the Co’s bondholders’ restructuring plan, made by the likes of PIMCO and Elliott, which could force them to initiate a “complex litigation” as soon as this week, which could boost the value of their claims against the Co by an additional USD 2bln.
  • Synthorx Inc (THOR) (Health Care/Biotechnology) is to be acquired by Sanofi (SNY, SAN FP) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) for USD 68/share in cash, at an equity value of USD 2.5bln, over two times THOR’s last closing price of USD 25.03. The California-based biotech Co is expected to boost Sanofi’s oncology and immuno-oncology offerings.

BROKER MOVES

ArcelorMittal (MT NA) - Italian PM Conte has stated that negotiations with the Co. regarding the ILVA steelworks has just begun; denying allegations regarding a payout., ANSA

subject: Pemex CEO says crude production will close 2019 at 1.778mln BPD, but will rise to 1.819mln BPD in January
analysis_details:
• As a comparison, Pemex output averaged 1.66mln BPD in October.
  • Note: In September, the Mexican Deputy FinMin said he wanted Pemex to achieve a production rate of 1.8mln BPD for December.

subject: Desk is monitoring a report from Canada which suggests a Canadian Pacific Railway train hauling crude oil derailed, causing a fire; no injuries reported
NY Fed 28-day repo operation oversubscribed with Fed accepting USD 25bln of USD 43bln in bids
analysis_details:
• UBS on the weekend wrote that since the repo flare up in mid-September, the Fed was prompted to respond with repo operations, and rates participants have been closely watching for signs that funding market will continue to experience volatility in the month of December, and particularly at year-end.
  • UBS says term repo markets are currently pricing another year-end spike in funding tightness, which could prompt the Fed to respond with more measures to ensure the market doesn't lose confidence in their ability to control their fed effective policy rate.
  • Others note that the oversubscription at 172%, nearly matches the oversubscriptions on 25/Nov (192%) and 2/Dec (170%), and therefore, markets should be on the lookout for increased sizes and more repo operations that cover over year end.
  • The next schedule is released Thursday.

subject: North Korean official says US President Trump's remarks over the weekend sound like a threat, but are a sign of fear; official warns that Trump may need to rethink, or face catastrophic consequences
analysis_details:
• Over the weekend, North Korea state media reported it carried out a "very important" test at its Sohae satellite launch site, a testing facility that US officials had previously said Pyongyang had pledged to close. 
  • US President Trump tweeted NK leader Kim was "too smart and has far too much to lose, everything actually, if he acts in a hostile way."

subject: Italy PM says government expects to make a decision on Atlantia's (ATL IM) motorway concessions by the end of the year
Germany CDU general secretary Ziemiak says CDU cannot renegotiate the coalition agreement, but there is scope for marginal modifications
content: • Adds that working with the SPD is not going to get easier when looking at the party's move towards the left
analysis_details: The SPD's new leadership has sounded constructive on continuing the government coalition with the CDU; however, analysts note it may be due to the fact that SPD is polling poorly at the moment, lessening the appeal for them to force any snap elections.

subject: Iran's budget for next year eyes an oil price of USD 50 per barrel, according to Iranian press Shana
analysis_details: On the weekend, Iran President Rouhani announced a USD 39bln "budget of resistance" to counter US sanctions, following a fuel price rise that sparked deadly nationwide protests. Over the weekend, the oil price assumption that the budget was based on was not disclosed.

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - USD Retains a Soft Undertone, Focus on Event Risk
content:
•   USD mixed ahead of FOMC; markets unwind post-NFP euphoria
  •   CAD choppy but unchanged from Friday’s weak jobs data
  •   EUR edges higher on better-than-expected German trade figures

subject: Ahead of this week's Chinese CPI data, SCMP reports China’s pig numbers rise, but supplies are still tight before Lunar New Year holiday, according to its agriculture ministry
content: • National herd grows by 2%, as authorities under pressure to ensure there is enough pork for the holiday, SCMP reported
analysis_details:
• NOTE: China CPI data is released on Tuesday; Consumer prices are likely to firm in November, with the Y/Y rate rising to 4.2% from 3.8%, according to the consensus. PPI is also likely to firm, though will likely remain negative at -1.5% Y/Y. The rise may be on the back of base effects, given fuel and food prices fell sharply in November 2018. 
  • However, looking through the base effects, SocGen says pork prices will remain a source of upward pressure, though wholesale prices have already begun moderating in the month on rising imports and stabilisation of pork supply; however, pork prices are still over 10% higher in November, and will thus likely contribute to the rise. Elsewhere, other components are seen stable.

subject: Libya NOC declares force majeure on Mellitah crude loadings; follows shutdown of El Feel, sources said
Merck (MRK) is to acquire Arqule (ARQL) for an equity value of USD 2.7bln
UBS notes this is seasonally the weakest week for equities in Q4
analysis_details:
• This week is seasonally the weakest in Q4 since 1980, UBS strategists note, with an average SPX return of -0.25%, with negative performance 56% of years. But, the bank says that strong US payrolls on Friday, along with choppy trade headlines, leave markets biased to the upside into year-end with clear event risks.
  • This week sees the release of FOMC (Wed, expected unchanged), ECB (Thu, expected unchanged with a message of continuity and ‘consensus’); Trade-related headlines continue to provide risks ahead of the 15th December tariff deadline; trade impacted stocks were +1.1% last week outperforming the MSCI global large cap index by about 150bps. UBS says that historically, DAX, EM, Materials, Autos, and Semis have the strongest correlation to the performance of its trade baskets, with both DAX and EEM implied volatility below average with elevated skew.
  • Last week, cyclical performance was uneven, which could suggest portfolio managers are playing "prevent defence" to preserve gains into year-end by holding a safe core portfolio, and using call options on growth sensitive indices or selectively buying cyclicals as an upside hedge. Low volatility stocks remain highly correlated with 12-month momentum to but no longer again 1-month momentum, UBS notes, which suggests recent leadership has a more risk-on bias.
  • UBS notes call options on IWM (R2K, high US growth beta) and EEM (EM ETF, trade headline sensitive) are most attractive for the "prevent defence" theme; both have low implied volatility and high skew versus the last five-years.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 9th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are tentative as newsflow is limited ahead of a key week
  • China’s trade data was weaker than expected, with exports surprisingly contracting though imports did post surprise growth
  • USTR Lighthizer and US Democrats are reportedly nearing a deal for Congress to pass USMCA, although hurdles remain
  • UK Election polls have around an 8-14pp spread in the Conservative-Labour lead, YouGov MRP to be released tomorrow
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US 3yr Supply, RBA’s Lowe

TRADE

China ordered government offices and public institutions to remove all foreign computer equipment and software in 3 years. (Newswires)

China top diplomat Yang spoke with US Secretary of State Pompeo on Saturday in which he stated the US has seriously violated international relations by passing the Hong Kong and Uighur bills, while he urged the US to correct its mistakes and immediately stop interfering with China’s internal affairs. (Newswires) China’s Xinjiang region Governor said the US bill on Xinjiang is a severe violation of international law, while the Governor added the US bill has no regard for facts and has made groundless accusations against the human rights situation as well as the Chinese government. (Newswires)

China is to lower tariffs further at an appropriate time., Mofcom. (Newswires) Unclear on exactly what tariffs the spokesman is referring to with this remark. Elsewhere, China Global Times Chief Editor tweets that "Because of US obstruction, WTO's appellate body which settles disputes between members will be unable to function on Tuesday. And it is the most important platform to ensure fair trade."

China's President Xi hopes to achieve a China-EU investment agreement as soon as is possible., Chinese State TV. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed as the tailwinds from Friday’s stellar US NFP report was offset by mostly weaker than expected Chinese trade data including a surprise contraction in Exports and with some hesitation observed heading into a risk-packed week. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) saw a firm start to the session led by outperformance in energy names following the OPEC+ agreement, although both indices briefly retraced the majority of their gains amid heavy losses in Australia’s gold miners and as recent JPY strength suppressed the effect of a firm upward revision to Q3 GDP. Hang Seng (U/C) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.4%) traded indecisively after the largely disappointing Chinese trade data and as China continued to voice discontent with US “interference” regarding the Hong Kong protests and Uighur Muslims. Furthermore, China reportedly denied entrance into Macau for the President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong and have also ordered government offices and public institutions to remove all foreign computer equipment and software in 3 years. Finally, 10yr JGBs declined on spill-over selling from T-notes and with the pressure also a function of the gains in stocks, firm GDP revisions and tepid BoJ Rinban announcement valued at JPY 180bln.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0405 vs. Exp. 7.0400 (Prev. 7.0383)

Hong Kong protesters conducted a large-scale march which organizers claimed a turnout of 800k but police only estimated 183k, which was largely peaceful although a few fires were set at the entrance of the High Court and Court of Final Appeal. Furthermore, the protests have reached a 6th month milestone, while analysts suggested Hong Kong retail businesses could experience 15% decline in holidays sales and restaurants may suffer 30% drop in sales from the protests. (Newswires)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Nov) 38.73B vs. Exp. 46.3B (Prev. 42.81B). (Newswires) Chinese Exports (USD)(Nov) Y/Y -1.1% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. -0.9%) Chinese Imports (USD)(Nov) Y/Y 0.3% vs. Exp. -1.8% (Prev. -6.4%) Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Nov) 274.2B vs. Exp. 294.0B (Prev. 301.3B). (Newswires) Chinese Exports (USD)(Nov) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 2.1%) Chinese Imports (USD)(Nov) Y/Y 2.5% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. -3.5%)

Japanese GDP (Q3 F) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires) Japanese GDP (Q3 F) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.2%)

GEOPOLITICS

In related news, there were also Twitter reports of sirens sounding near Baghdad International Airport in Iraq from potential rockets targeting the airport. (Newswires)

White House National Security Adviser O'Brien warned US has many tools to deal with North Korea if it reneges on denuclearization commitments. (Newswires) Subsequently, North Korean Official notes that Pyongyang has nothing to lose, in response to US President Trump., Yonhap. Refers to: US President Trump stating that North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un could void the special relationship, occurring during reports that NK conducted tests at missile sites US

USTR Lighthizer and US Democrats are reportedly nearing a deal for Congress to pass USMCA, although hurdles remain according to reports citing sources familiar with the discussions. (WSJ)

Mexico Foreign Minister Ebrard said Mexico will not accept US labor inspections in USMCA trade pact and will not accept US steel proposal for USMCA without 5-year period to go into effect, while he added that over 90% of USMCA is not open to revision, but there will be an addendum to the deal. (Newswires)

Bank for International Settlements stated that the turmoil in the repo market during September was exacerbated by hedge funds borrowing cash to bolster returns on their trades and also suggested the reluctance of banks to lend was also a key factor. (FT)

UK/EU

UK Election Polls: Have the Conservatives lead over Labour at 14pp at best, with a spread of around 8-14pp across polls. Note, the second YouGov MRP will be released on Tuesday

-        BMG Research poll: Conservatives 41% (+2), Labour 32% (-1), Lib Dems 14% (+1), Brexit Party 4% (Unch.), December 4th-6th

-        Deltapoll poll: Conservatives 44% (-1), Labour 33% (+1), Lib Dems 11% (-4), Brexit Party 3% (Unch.), December 5th-7th.

-        Opinium poll: Conservatives 46% (Unch.), Labour 31% (Unch.), Lib Dems 13% (Unch.), Brexit Party 2% (Unch.), December 4th-6th.

-        Savanta/ComRes poll: Conservatives 42% (Unch.), Labour 36% (+4), Lib Dems 11% (-1), Brexit Party 4% (+1), December 2nd-5th.

-        Survation/Good Morning Britain poll: Conservatives 45% (+2), Labour 31% (-2), Lib Dems 11% (Unch.), Brexit Party 4% (+1), December 5th-7th

-        UK Election YouGov poll: Conservatives 43% (+1), Labour 33% (unch), Lib Dems 13% (+1), Brexit Party 3% (-1), December 5th-6th.

-        DataPraxis MRP Model suggest Conservatives will win 344 seats (+27), Labour 221 (-41), Lib Dems 14 (+2), SNP 47 (+12).

A leaked Department for Exiting the EU document seen by the FT has revealed warnings that implementing Boris Johnson’s Brexit deal would see Northern Ireland remain as part of the EU customs code, subsequently presenting “major” challenges. (FT)

French Finance Minister says the nation is prepared to go to the WTO to challenge US President Trump’s threat to put tariffs on certain US goods. (CNBC)

German Trade Balance, EUR, SA* (Oct) 20.6B vs. Exp. 19.0B (Prev. 19.2B); Exports MM SA* (Oct) 1.2% vs. Exp. -0.7% (Prev. 1.5%). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities kick the week off broadly lower, albeit marginally [Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%] after the NFP optimism waned and as sub-par Chinese data dented the mood. Sectors are mostly in the red – and with no clear standouts and little by way of a split between cyclicals and defensives to reflect the risk tone, although material names are underpinned by the Friday’s surge in base-metal prices. In terms of individual movers: Osram Licht (+14.4%) soared to the top of the pan-EU index after AMS (-3.0%) announced it has succeeded on its second attempt with a EUR 4.6bln bid for Osram which comes after it lowered the necessary acceptance rate to 55% vs. Prev. 62.5%. Elsewhere, Tesco shares (+5.4%) are supported after confirming exploration of options for its Thai and Malaysian units (which account for 10% of Co’s sales), including a possible sale which could fetch up to USD 9bln. Meanwhile, Just Eat (+0.5%) shares are underpinned after Prosus increased its offer for the Co. to GBP 7.40/shr, valuing the Co. at approx. GBP 5.1bln; additionally, acceptance level for the deal has been reduced to a simple majority. Number 10 shareholder Cat Rock (owns 2.6% of Just Eat) noted that Prosus’ offer needs to be at least GBP 9.25.shr to compete with Takeaway.com’s offer. Takeaway.com believe that their offer for the Co. remains ‘far superior’ to the Prosus one. On the flip side, Tullow Oil (-59.0%) shares plummeted after the Co. was hit by a double whammy in the form of a production outlook downgrade and the departure of its CEO. Other downside movers include the likes of Sanofi (-0.5%) and Kerry Group (-0.9%) – both on M&A news – with the former acquiring Synthorx for USD 2.5bln, whilst the latter is reportedly mulling acquiring DuPont’s Nutrition business – which could be valued around USD 25bln.

FX

GBP - Sterling is off best levels, but still firmly bid as the clock ticks down to Thursday’s GE and polls continue to flag victory for the Tories, albeit to varying degrees and ahead of the final YouGov MRP due to be published tomorrow evening. Indeed, the Pound continues to outperform G10 counterparts and is defying a broadly risk-off start to the week on the back of disappointing Chinese trade data that is undermining high beta currencies and those with closest connections naturally. Cable extended gains to circa 1.3181 at one stage, while Eur/Gbp probed just below 0.8400 before running into offers and bids respectively.

AUD/CAD/NZD - Predictably, the Aussie is bearing the brunt of the aforementioned smaller than forecast Chinese trade surplus that was largely due to an unexpected drop in exports, with Aud/Usd hovering around 0.6425 and Aud/Nzd retesting support ahead of 1.0400, like a 1.0407 Fib that only just held las Friday. Meanwhile, the Kiwi is pivoting 0.6550 vs its US peer and the Loonie is trying to pare losses in wake of starkly contrasting NA labour data in a relatively tight range either side of 1.3250 ahead of Canadian housing starts and building permits.

JPY/EUR/CHF - All narrowly mixed against the Greenback, as the DXY meanders between 97.602-725 parameters, but with the Yen benefiting from a grinding safe-haven bid and picking away at stops said to be sitting south of 108.50, while the Euro is straddling 1.1065 and Franc 0.9900 in the run up to ECB and SNB policy meetings hot on the heels of the Fed.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi Crowns are also feeling the adverse effects averse sentiment, as Eur/Sek rebounds towards 10.5500 and Eur/Nok nudges off sub-10.1000 lows on the back of technically delayed and mixed monthly Norwegian GDP prints for October.

EM - The Lira looks somewhat unimpressed with Turkey’s efforts to spur bank lending via targeted RRR tweaks, as Usd/Try trades close to 5.800 and multi-month peaks.

South Africa's Eskom has, this morning, lost additional generation units which has increased unplanned breakdowns to 14200MW; flooding at some power stations, further impairing supply. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and holding just below a new Eurex high of 172.44 and the base of a small resistance zone protecting an even more pronounced bounce from post-NFP lows that could expose 172.50 ahead of 172.66. However, outperformance elsewhere in the Eurozone, such as Italian BTPs and Spanish Bonos ahead of Thursday’s ECB meeting may also be capping the core debt future, while Gilts remain off best levels on UK election positioning and hedging for a conclusive outcome rather than no clear result. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are also nursing some losses after Friday’s strong NFP releases and the curve is fractionally flatter ahead of a data-less session, but supply via Usd38 bn 3 year notes.

COMMODITIES 

The energy complex continues to drift lower following last week’s OPEC-induced surge in prices which received tailwinds from a blockbuster US jobs report. WTI Jan’20 futures have re-dipped below the 59/bbl mark whilst Brent Feb’20 futures gave up the USD 64/bbl in EU trade, with the magnitudes of the moves relatively tepid compared to Friday’s upside action. Analysts at ING believe that the action taken by OPEC+ (500k BPD deeper cuts and Saudi’s 400k BPD voluntary cuts on top of earlier curtailed output) will continue to support prices, thus the bank sees ICE Brent averaging USD 60/bbl in Q1 next year, with Q2 outlook contingent on the cartel’s next move in early March. ING note that upside risks to their forecast includes significant supply disruptions and meaningful progress on the US-China front. On that note, BofA expects Brent could be boosted to USD 70/bbl in the case of strong OPEC+ compliance and positive economic developments. Elsewhere, spot gold holds onto most of Friday’s losses with prices fluctuating within a relatively tight band ahead of its 21 DMA at USD 1464.65/oz and a risk-packed week. Copper has pared some of Friday’s gains as prices are modestly pressured by the latest Chinese trade data (which came in narrower than forecasts in USD and CNY terms) but cushioned by the breakdown, in which imports topped estimates and China copper imports hit a 13-month high on improved factory activity. Finally, iron ore prices feel little reprieve after November iron ore imports from China fell for a second straight month.

BofA says Brent prices could be boosted to USD 70/bbl ahead of schedule due to in the case of strong OPEC+ compliance coupled with positive economic developments. (Newswires)

Venezuela government and opposition are reportedly considering providing private oil companies operating rights including Chevron (CVX), Rosneft and CNPC, although PDVSA would hold a majority stake according to sources. (Newswires)

Iron ore options began trading in the Dalian Commodity Exchange today. (Newswires)

subject: ANALYSIS: US tariff deadline of 15th December 2019 approaches
analysis_details:
• Tariffs on the remaining USD c.160bln worth of Chinese imports to the US could take effect if US President Trump is not satisfied with progress in trade talks with China by 15th December 2019. The 15% duties would largely target consumer goods, including mobile phones, laptop and desktop computers, toys and clothing.
  • China demands the US remove existing tariffs imposed on around USD 375bln worth of its exports to the US, and cancel the impending tariff hike on 15th December; the US demands China commit to specific minimum purchases of US agricultural products, and make concessions on intellectual property rights, currency and access to China’s financial services sectors.
  • To judge how much is priced in for US/China tariffs, UBS suggests keeping an eye on TY risk reversals as a rates gauge for US-China and economic fundamental sentiment; it notes that the lows in August marked peak negative sentiment around data and US-China, while the highs in November signalled some data stabilization and Phase 1 deal expectations along with hopes of current tariff rollback. UBS says that adjusted for economic data being less worse than in August, the range between -0.7 and +0.4 should provide guideposts here of where Phase 1 deal expectations becomes stretched one way or the other.
  • Desks are on the lookout for two key catalysts: 1) Any indication that the US would delay the 15th December tariff boost, or any more warmer noises on potential tariff rollbacks; 2) any commentary which suggests that the two sides are preparing to meet face-to-face, which may signal agreement on a deal ‘in principle’.
  • Elsewhere, analysts are also watching the US/China dynamic outside of trade to assess the likelihood a deal can be agreed. Last month President Trump signed a bill mandating an annual review to check if Hong Kong has enough autonomy to justify its special status with the US, in a sign of support of pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong. Last week, the House passed legislation to sanction any Chinese officials connected to the alleged human rights violations of Uighurs (Senate will likely do the same soon). These issues have angered Chinese officials, some suggest that while they have not derailed trade talks, how these and other issues outside of trade are resolved could be key in determining the success of the trade negotiations.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures tracking the broad post-NFP rebound
content: It’s been a bit more measured and reserved, if not quite reluctant as such, but UK debt and STIR contracts have conformed to the general recovery trend in wake of the fallout prompted by Friday’s bullish US labour report. Gilts resumed Liffe just above 132.00 and regrouped after an early wobble that pushed prices down to 131.95, with the bounce strong enough to lift the 10 year bond into chart resistance between 123.23-28, though not sufficient to clear the zone and test a stronger upside objective at 133.35 (last Wednesday’s intraday peak and close to the 50 DMA). Domestic markets have more than one eye on the upcoming election and Sterling’s resurgence as polls point to an outright win for PM Johnson’s Conservative Party. Hence, relative underperformance in UK debt and along the 3 month strip on the premise that even a slim majority for the Tories is better than a hung parliament and yet more Brexit inaction.

Bunds: paring US payroll losses with the aid of sub-forecast Chinese trade data
content: The 10 year German benchmark has bounced firmly off overnight lows and continues to grind higher in consolidative trade following last Friday’s post-US jobs data slide, with the core Eurozone debt future just easing back from a 172.33 recovery high. No visible reaction to a larger than expected German trade surplus, but risk sentiment has been ruffled by another drop in exports from China that confounded the consensus for a rebound and more than offset a surprise rise in imports to leave the surplus short of the median estimate. Bunds are now looking elsewhere for further inspiration and direction, as EU cash bourses return to the fray on the back foot, albeit modestly, while the technical backdrop remains constructive above 172.00 and support around 172.12 on some charts vs resistance between 172.44-46.

content:

9th December 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed as the tailwinds from Friday’s stellar US NFP report was offset by mostly weaker than expected Chinese trade data including a surprise contraction in Exports and with some hesitation observed heading into a risk-packed week. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) saw a firm start to the session led by outperformance in energy names following the OPEC+ agreement to deepen output curbs by 500k bpd and Saudi pledge of an additional voluntary cut of 400k bpd, although both indices briefly retraced the majority of their gains amid heavy losses in Australia’s gold miners and as recent JPY strength suppressed the effect of a firm upward revision to Q3 GDP. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) traded indecisive after the largely disappointing Chinese trade data and as China continued to voice discontent with US “interference” regarding the Hong Kong protests and Uighur Muslims. Furthermore, China reportedly denied entrance into Macau for the President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong and have also ordered government offices and public institutions to remove all foreign computer equipment and software in 3 years.

Co. would not confirm the identity of any interested parties and said no decision has been made yet. The Thai and Malaysian operations account for around 10% of Co’s group sales. (Times/FT)
